0.title: Adult Dosing
0.mono:
• Actinic keratosis: apply TOPICALLY to target lesion(s) on face or scalp and let dry, then repeat once; 14 to 18 hr later, gently rinse area with water and pat dry; follow by 1000 sec of illumination from the BLU-U(R) Blue Light Photodynamic Therapy Illuminator; may retreat a second time after 8 wk
  • Actinic keratosis: protect treated lesions from sunlight or prolonged or intense light for at least 40 hr by covering with light-opaque material; sunscreen will not protect against photosensitivity reactions caused by visible light

1.title: Pediatric Dosing
1.mono: safety and effectiveness have not been established in children under 18 years of age

3.title: Indications
3.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
Actinic keratosis
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Basal cell carcinoma of skin
  • Squamous cell carcinoma

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• Cutaneous photosensitivity at wavelengths of 400 to 450 nanometers
  • Patients with porphyria
  • Allergies to porphyrins
  • Sensitivity to any of the components of the Levulan(R) Kerastick(TM) for topical solution

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Do not apply to eyes or mucous membranes
  • Avoid exposure of treated areas to sunlight or bright indoor light prior to blue light treatment; Sunscreens will NOT protect the patient from photosensitivity reactions
  • Avoid application of solution to perilesional areas; excessive irritation may occur if applied under occlusion
  • Possibility of increased photosensitivity reaction when used concomitantly with other known photosensitizing agents

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
Dermatologic:Bleeding (mild or moderate, 2% to 4%; severe, 0%), Disorder of skin pigmentation (22% to 36%), Edema (35%), Erythema (99%), Flare reaction (mild or moderate, 2% to 7%; severe, 0% to 1%), Pruritus (mild or moderate, 14% to 25%; severe, 1% to 7%), Pustule (0% to 4%), Scaly skin (mild or moderate, 64% to 71%; severe, 1% to 2%), Sensation of burning of skin, Skin ulcer (mild or moderate, 2% to 4%; severe, 0%), Stinging of skin, Superficial ulcer of skin, Skin erosion (mild or moderate, 2% to 14%; severe, 0% to 1%), Vesicular eruption (mild or moderate, 4% to 5%; severe, 0%)

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono: aminolevulinic acid (ALA) is a prodrug which is metabolized to the photosensitizer, protoporphyrin IX (PpIX), causing it to accumulate intracellularly in the skin where applied; light excitation of PpIX in the presence of oxygen causes a photodynamic reaction, resulting in a local cytotoxic effect

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono:
• Hepatic; extent unknown
  • Active metabolite: protoporphyrin IX, in the skin

4.title: Elimination Half Life
4.mono:
• Aminolevulinic acid: (oral) 0.7 h, (IV) 0.83 h
  • Protoporphyrin IX: (topical, solution) 30 h (lesions), 28 h (perilesional skin)

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
Topical
  • with the applicator cap pointing up, crush the bottom ampule, then crush the top ampule and continue crushing downward; point the applicator cap away from the face and gently shake the applicator for at least 30 sec to completely dissolve the drug
  • complete solution application within 2 hr of preparation and discard applicator; use new applicator if application is not complete within 2 hr
  • do not apply or allow contact to the periorbital, ocular, or mucosal surfaces
  • not recommended to treat both the face and scalp areas simultaneously
  • following application, do not wash the areas prior to photosensitization
  • at light illumination, rinse area with gently with water and pat dry
  • photoactivation is accomplished with a 1000 sec exposure to blue light (to provide a 10 Joules/square centimeter light dose) with a BLU-U(R) Blue Light Photodynamic Therapy Illuminator, 14 to 18 hr after application of the solution
  • after photosensitization, protect treated lesions from sunlight or prolonged or intense light for at least 40 hr by covering with light-opaque material; sunscreen will not protect against photosensitivity reactions caused by visible light

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• Instruct patient to avoid exposure of treated areas to sunlight or bright indoor light prior to the blue light treatment, as this may cause a photosensitivity reaction. Sunscreen will not protect patient from this reaction.
  • This drug may cause erythema, flare reaction, pruritus, skin stinging, or superficial ulceration of the skin.
